author: Justin English

text:
I don't want to sound to like a troll, but personally I didn't like Lost Odyssey very much despite being a huge JRPG fan. I didn't like the characters both for character design and their personalities (Kaim's kids were especially annoying to me), the music was so-so (at least by Uematsu standards) and the gameplay wasn't exciting either. I don't think it's a bad game, but the reputation of being the best JRPG of that generation is heavily overblown, in my opinion.
On a side note, I do like this track though.

text: Same, actually. The best way I can describe it is that it does nothing wrong, but does nothing right at the same time. A shame really, I had hopes that it would be its generations "Rogue Galaxy" in terms of being a hidden gem.

text: Imagine what would have happened if Hironobu Sakaguchi, Nobuo Uematsu and the rest of former Square people that formed Mistwalker, had stuck around for Final Fantasy XIII? It would have probably been like this. I think their awesomeness was channeled into this game. I know that people left the company for one reason or another, but imagine what FFXIII could have been like if the people that helped create the series were able to have some input on what is considered to be the worst game in the main numbered Final Fantasy games.

text: Is Blue Dragon a good game? Is it similar to Lost Odyssey?
author: Joakim West

text: Yeah Blue Dragon is a very good game, I can't recommend it enough:) It's very similar to Lost Odyssey because it's made by the same company, they're both turn based RPGs, Lost Odyssey has a ring system while in Blue Dragon they summon their shadows that take the form of a mythological being that gives them extra skills. Both games have a beautiful soundtrack composed by Nobuo Uematsu:D I found the story very good but don't expect a mature, dark story and atmosphere like in Lost Odyssey. While Blue Dragon can have its dark moments too it's a light hearted story with beautiful artwork by Akira:) Sorry if it was too long but I really love Lost Odyssey and Blue Dragon.

text:
Indeed, it's such a shame that this game got overlooked because "it's old style and turn-based": it was a time where turn-based games were all ignored because considered "old and ancient", and yet Persona 5 proved us how Turn based JRPGs can still kick ass no matter what.

PS: I also know this game got ignored because released on xbox too.

author: Pepsimaru
BrokenMoonStudios

text:
@BrokenMoonStudios I think you're right on that one: I had an xbox but I barely played it and despite owning vesperia and this (and eternal sonata) I didn't see too many other games on it, which is a shame.


However I do mean it when I say that back then turn style rpgs were suddenly becoming "too old" for some reason and this made most devs shift their games into a mix of turn-based and action that MANY TIMES wouldn't work (Ni no Kuni, White Knight Chronicles, Final Fantasy 13 and Eternal Sonata comes to mind). 
If you have a goddamn bar to wait before attacking it's NOT action: it's turn-based disguised as action (at least in my opinion)


I'm just glad that those horrible hybrids are now over and we get proper action rpgs (ys, tales or Shining resonance) or proper turn-based rpgs (persona, digimon cybersleuth)

author: AgileFan0

text: FF7 was okay, but hardly what I'd call "setting the bar".  It was 3D, that was IT.  That's all everybody raved about.  Not the spikey-haired emo guy, not the effeminate bad guy with long silver hair, just that it was in 3D.  FF6 had a better story, better characters, and even today still looks better despite being 2D.
author: InsanoRider777

text:
Nope, FF7 was and still is one of the greatest JRPG's to date. It set the bar in graphics, style, music and as far as I'm concerned, story. That's not to say that all other games were no good before or after FF7, just that it was a new take on what an RPG could be, on how to tell stories and a fantastic world without the traditional fantasy settings.
If you don't agree, that's fine, but to me you kind of sound like you're just trolling. Cloud was, and still is, one of the greatest heroes of our age, and emo is taking it quite a bit too far, I think. I've played and replayed it, and I don't think he's all that emo, not if you look at the whole picture. Sure, he's whiny in the beginning with all the "pay me"-stuff, but I don't think we'd be calling you an emo if your only true rolemodel turned his back on you, killed everyone you know and love and then went on a killingspree with the ultimate goal of destroying the entire planet. I think we'd be calling you one tough SoB for just being sad and angry, being able to interact with people at all. There's a difference between being emo and actually being hurt, IMO.
author: Pinkaugust

text: @Pinkaugust I actually prefer FF6....but FF7 had really great moments too.  FF7 had a lot of questions that a) were left open to interpretation or b) had answers that were very subtle.  That's why it's such a talked about game.  That and the fact that it was such a huge leap at the time in terms of graphics.  In terms of music, however, FF6 has some of Uematsu's best work.  He named it as his favorite OST when asked.  Lost Odyssey's music comes pretty close though, IMO.
author: DivineAria

text: @Pinkaugust Exactly. Some people gain a false feeling of self-importance just because they're with the different crowd. The FFVI crowd is sometimes awfully pretentious. Those who like FFVII more don't go around insulting FFVI everywhere, and yes (to @InsanoRider777), I'm talking about those who have played both games.

text: VI had a much darker and somber tone in comparison to VII. The cast of characters were far more memorable IMO. The scene with Celes after the world of ruin initiates is so emotionally impacting. Every character is just so driven by what they have been through. Even Gau has a bit of a somber story... There's an optional quest involving him recollecting memories of his father. His theme plays as he finally meets his father. The feels man! Lol.

text:
yeah, tbh Squeenix has thoroughly disappointed me ever since FF10-2. (I'm actually semi-alright with the first FF10) FF13 is just part of the pop-induced gloss-fest they've got going. Pop is only ok if distributed evenly.
So when I discovered Lost Odyssey, this was like a godsend for me.

I have to say though... FF15 actually looks promising. I hope I'm not wrong about it and it doesn't suddenly become another chick-flick--like everything succeeding Square and Enix's merger has turned out to be.

author: badflamer

text: What he described was more like a mix of Tidus and like, Hope. Especially the "THIS IS MY STORY" part, which Tidus says over and over again, despite FFX being about Yuna. Tidus also whines a ton, while never going straight into "emo" territory. Also, Squall was nothing like that. And all of the times he was frustrated it was in his head. He didn't usually vocalize how much things pissed him off, and just kept doing what needed to be done. Which is why Squall is just cold, rather than emo/whiny.

text: I agree, though there are some FF main characters that don't seem to be broody because they don't have much of a reason to be, like Zidane, Tidus, and Terra. And Cloud of course is put down for what you are describing, but personally thanks to playing Crisis Core I do think he has a reason for being the way he is. Squall on the other hand is the perfect example of what you're describing, can't stand him because of that. But yes, I do agree with you, one of the many reasons this is one of my favs
author: Lunar Blossom

text: See I love this game far more than any final fantasy because the hero has a legitimate reason for why he's as sad and brooding as he is. He's lived a thousand years and seen countless deaths, lost people he cared about and had his life ripped apart by a former comrade. It seems to carry a lot more weight than "my life sucks, boohoo, gotta save the world, this is MY story", etc. that so many FF chars seem to whine about.

text: When Uematsu is on top of his game, he is almost peerless, as 1:14 - 1:32 shows.
author: Dallas J Reeves

text: Yeah, exactly. I agree that the technical issues lie in the poor choice of console, and that's not really the game's fault. With a different console and more special moves added, the gameplay would be perfect. Spamming gale slash and diffusing magic circles was fun, but only for a while. I was also disappointed with the complete lack of character customization, though. Overall, though, I personally found TLS's story and characters more engaging, but still, LO is still strong there, too.
author: swordfish1390

text: Agreed that TLS had some technical problems. As you mentioned, the game had some frame rate/lag issues but I kind of attribute much of that to the power of the Wii. I wouldn't mind a little more polish to the battle system myself. It offered plenty of different elements(stealth, first person, command, gathering, etc) but adding more specials, attack moves, and/or magic spells would be a nice touch. Overall though, gotta say I had a blast and enjoyed every battle vs wanting to run at times in LO.
author: DivineAria

text: I agree that the story/characters in LO were great, but I preferred them in TLS. I don't know why, but I found them more engaging and the story more worthwhile, in my opinion, but Lost Odyssey was still great in that department. However, I am sorry to say, but I personally did not care for the combat in TLS. It was unique and fun at times, but there are a lot of graphical and presentational issues (Lag, framerate drops, etc), as well as bizarre control schemes. This is just my opinion, though.
author: swordfish1390

text: I prefer Lost Odyssey.  It was just simply more memorable and epic, especially in the story/characters/music department...but if you're talking about the fun factor, TLS was unique and probably the most fun JRPG I've ever played.  Combat was extremely addicting and I liked how non-tedious the game was compared to your typical JRPG.  LO=9.7/10, TLS=9.3/10.  Both are great games though, really.  Gonna have to play Blue Dragon too now.  Yay, Mistwalker!
author: DivineAria

text: Lost Odyssey is so fucking awesome.... I'll probably get hate for this, but I like Last Story a little bit more >___>

text: Both.  It's more similar to the older FF games in both how it plays and how great of a game it is.  Of course, the fact that Sakaguchi, Uetmatsu, and other old Square Soft members were involved with this game is a huge factor as well.  I also own this game's soundtrack.  I feel it's one of Uematsu's strongest.  The music is just as soulful and emotional as the game itself.

text: Lost Odyssey is amazing.  It has a very down-to-earth story, great characters, and one of the best soundtracks I've heard in a long time.  If you're a huge FF fan, definitely give it a shot because it's more Final Fantasy than anything titled that this gen.

text: The only downside to being a Mistwalker/Sakaguchi fan is that they jump console a lot.  Luckily, I own all three major consoles.
author: DivineAria

text:
I've played XIII and I haven't played this. Went over to a friend's house one day to check it out while he was working on a boss, and was sold in ten seconds. I'm GETTING a 360 for this game. SOLELY for this game. Why?

Because somehow this is where "Final Fantasy" actually went. Forget the title, the awesomeness is here.
author: Hawk

text: I have Xenoblade and am about 7-8 hours into the game.  While I loved every moment of Lost Odyssey, I'm having some trouble trying to stay interested in the other.  Different tastes for different people, I guess.  There's so much heart and sentiment in LO that it makes Xenoblade feel a little, for the lack of a better term, dry in comparison.  Sure, you can do a lot more exploring Xeno...but overwhelming exploration doesn't necessarily make for a better game.

author: zubitz

text:
@brainjuice654  This game didn't sell well.  The gameplay is tedious.  And the pacing is bad.  Kaim's amnesia was revealed so prematurely that the story was laid bare 10 hours into the gameplay.  

But the real travesty was the gameplay.  It was absolutely repetetive.  And the mage characters who wore staffs: there was no point in even upgrading their weapon.   Look at shin megami tensei games for how "traditional" style battles can be fun.
author: Herencian

text: @IdeonFukkatsu traditional battle systems are the best and always will be and vocals don't count as ost for all i care at least it doesn't have leona lewis >.< ff13 is one of the worst rpg's of this generation with it's long and repetitive bosses it's stupid compact commands. seriously i have more fun playing final fantasy 2 than 13 because it has way more character customization and it's the total opposite of linear and the classic turned based battle system. the atb bar idea in 13 sucked.
author: Terry 309

text: @brainjuice654  The combat system is archaic here.  They just copied last remnant's trigger hit sequence.  They used unreal engine for christ's sake.  The beginning of Lost Odyssey looks phenomenal, but once you clear that there's all kinds of graphical errors all through the game.  Not that it isn't a great game; but it was rushed and it's obvious.  Also Sheena Easton's song ruined any chance this game had at getting 10/10 score for ost.
author: Herencian

text: @IdeonFukkatsu i'd rather play this than any sega game and ff 13 is not even close to topping this
author: Terry 309

text: @IdeonFukkatsu  well lost odyssey could have been a little faster but still it's battle mechanics crush final fantasy 13's overly compact battle system, ff13 is bacically the devil may cry equivelent of final fantasy with repetitive and long boss fights
author: Terry 309

text: @Nanertot Because it isn't Final Fantasy, doesn't have any Final Fantasy elements in it that don't just classify as generic RPG elements, and because Final Fantasy was a Squaresoft/Square-Enix game, to name a few reasons.
author: AnubusStar

text: @Broshmosh Lost odyssey was super rushed, they made use of the unreal engine instead of writing their own, and as a result, we suffered the ring system which is a tired combat mechanic that has become very cliche.  I am NOT saying it's a bad game by any means, but the gameplay hurt badly compared to FF13 which was a lot more fun imo.  Best part of lost odyssey was 1000 years of dreams.
